posts.cooked:
Is there a convention for handling logic in the command based structure?

This is mostly about variants of the same thing that may call the same method while inputting a different parameter, i.e. the intake runs, but in different directions.

I have done this three different ways in the past and am not sure which one is considered ‘conventional’.

Every variant of an action has a separate command.

Every variant of an action has a separate command.

Both variants have the same command with the condition as a parameter and logic is handled in the command.

Both variants have the same command with the condition as a parameter and logic is handled in the command.

Both variants have the same command with the condition as a parameter and pass the parameter to the method called. Logic is handled in the subsystem.

Both variants have the same command with the condition as a parameter and pass the parameter to the method called. Logic is handled in the subsystem.

I know that all of these work, but is one of them better? I am looking to standardize next year.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.custom_user_title: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
Not sure what exactly is the convention, but I like to put the vast majority of the logic in the subsystem itself, and have the command be pretty dumb. That way I can use the command factory methods most of the time (Like Commands.run, runOnce, defer, etc). Only for some commands that need a bit of extra functionality do I create a separate command class to implement said functionality.

Most of the time I’m using the factory methods for commands, with one of the decorators (like finallyDo , etc).

posts.name: Jason Daming
posts.cooked:
TLDR: 3 and sometimes 2 but focus on the reasons not the rules.

I think a good place to start with a decision like this would be to evaluate the pros/cons of each method.  The proper decision may change over time but if you understand all of the reasons behind the decision when things change your decision can change with it as needed.

I am really struggling to this of the pros here and I think most of them would come down to simplicity.  The user doesn’t need to know how to pass parameters and the user could use method references all the time.  I think these are both really poor ideas as both of those things are pretty basic tenants.  This comes at the cost for a lot more verbosity and upkeep.

2/3 -  Really the crux of the decision here is does the logic go in the command or in the subsystem right?  I think the idea of standardizing for standards sake isn’t great.  Don’t standardize on one or the other or you must do X, standardize on a set of rules to use to make intelligent decisions going forward.

I think there are multiple different types of logic that can be needed here and those time are more conducive to being handled in different places.   I would call this Flow/State logic and IO logic (terms I just made up but I think they suffice).

Things that are heavy on managing variables and state are better suited be done in the command (you can call this command complexity, but I don’t think that is accurate).

Most everything else especially things more involving IO and contained subsystem logic is often better done in subsystem.  This keeps relevant logic together while also having easy access to all of the commonly needed pieces.  I would suggest however if you find yourself putting much of anything in the subsystem periodic there is probably a better way.  Not saying it can’t be used correctly just that it has a tendency to be overused incorrectly.

There are numerous other related decisions here like is it a multi subsystem command that can have effects.

posts.name: Jason Daming
posts.cooked:
I would argue that the top is never correct.  But the line gets more blurred if the top was say:

Vs.

My example is more about style and where you keep certain information.  Personally I kind of like having both options.

These are really simple examples however where I don’t think the line is blurry at all.  As the needs of the example gets significantly more complex so too does the problem.

Another idea that I don’t think you have even considered or discussed is having the subsystem return a command which cuts down on some of the extra typing and extra creation fluff you need in your caller.  At the expense of needing a better understanding of how to pass and handle the command datatype.

This is correct this is the classic object oriented approach. An object (generally a sub system and its associate commands/methods) should be self contained. Allowing you to changing the implementation and leave the related systems unaffected as long as the interfaces are the same.
